Chapter 8: The Ká¹£atriya's Reliance on the Wheel's Appearance
Furthermore, good sons!
The ten kinds of reliance practices and wheels are all the same for all Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and tathÄgatas.

If there are those who accomplish the reliance wheel, true good ká¹£atriyas, up to true good women, will quickly attain the dharma vessel of the Å›rÄvakas and the seeds of pratyekabuddhas, and will also be able to accomplish the tathÄgata's dharma vessel.
What are the ten?
Son of a great clan!

Namely, true and good ká¹£atriyas up to true and good women, whose bodily, verbal, and mental actions are pure in practicing the Dharma, who have a sense of shame and remorse, who detest their own bodies and fear the five aggregates, who do not see the other shore of the great river of birth and death, who delight in tranquility and avoid all confusion and noise, who have no contentious mind and do not criticize others' shortcomings, who guard the sense faculties and always keep the mind focused, who skillfully observe cause and effect and are able to accomplish meditation, who always delight in concentrating the mind and skillfully understand arising and ceasing, such people will be able to accomplish the ten wheels of reliance;

This is called true and good ká¹£atriyas up to true and good women who will quickly accomplish the vehicle of the hearers and the seeds of the pratyekabuddhas, and also attain the stage of nonretrogression in the Great Vehicle.
Thus, son of good family!

One is able to accomplish the vehicle of the hearers and pratyekabuddhas, relying on this wheel to cross the ocean of existence and enter the city of nirvana.ğŸ”½What is called the wheel of reliance on deportment?
What is called reliance?
What I call relying on the five aggregates of clinging is called reliance, and on the five aggregates of clinging one forms the notion of self and determines reliance.
What is called deportment?
There is the deportment of the aggregates and the deportment of the realms, this is called deportment.
What is called wheel?
The teachings upheld by the spiritual power of the buddhas are all called wheels and sword wheels.
Thus, Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas rely on this wheel to seek the path to nirvÄá¹‡a, attached to reliance, not fit to be the pure vessel of the MahÄyÄna.
What is called reliance?
Relying on the aggregates and realms, the mind gives rise to fear, relying on disgust, relying on the body to seek liberation, liberating one's own suffering with one's own aggregates.
In order to seek liberation for all beings, because of attachment to one's own aggregates, one is not able to receive the MahÄyÄna Dharma!
But they only act for themselves and not for sentient beings, lacking the mind of great compassion. For this reason, they do not abide in the Great Vehicle.

Abiding for a long time in saá¹ƒsÄra, they abandon the suffering of others. In order to eliminate their own afflictions, they are unable to give away their hands, feet, head, eyes, and so forth. For this reason, they are not vessels for the Dharma of the Great Vehicle, nor do they seek the wheel of the path of the Great Vehicle, nor do they seek the wheel of the Brahma voice. For this reason, they are not vessels for the Great Vehicle, and they enter the city of nirvÄá¹‡a alone without a companion.

For this reason, if there are sentient beings who have not heard the teachings of the ÅšrÄvakayÄna and PratyekabuddhayÄna, whose practices are incomplete, whose roots of goodness are not yet ripe, and whose diligence is slight;
If the Dharma is expounded before such people, both [the expounder and the listener] will incur offenses, and it will also disturb all the Buddhas.

For this reason, if there are sentient beings who have not matured their wholesome roots in the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle or the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle, if they listen to the subtle MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras, those people, out of foolishness, will consider themselves wise, fall into the view of annihilationism, and say that there is no cause and effect, no good or bad karma. They will also create chaos and confusion in my Dharma, saying that what is not the Dharma is the Dharma, that what is not the ascetic path is the ascetic path, and that what is not a bhiká¹£u is a bhiká¹£u. They will obstruct and cut off the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle and the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle and not disseminate them.

If one goes forth and receives the full monastic precepts in the Dharma of the ÅšrÄvakas and Pratyekabuddhas, in order to gather all wholesome roots, then whether one is a suitable vessel or not, whether one is a person in training or beyond training, if one skillfully speaks with unobstructed eloquence, has already realized the fruits, up to being a true good ordinary person who fully upholds the precepts, one should not scold, revile, or deprive them of their robes and alms bowl, or seize, bind, or imprison them.

Such people who hold views of annihilationism and eternalism are rÄká¹£asas among humans. It is difficult to obtain a human body. It is better to fall into hell and receive immeasurable offenses than to obtain a human body and give rise to the view of annihilationism;
Therefore, they are born stupid and their mouths cannot speak. Until the end of their lives, they will go to AvÄ«ci Hell, and it is difficult to obtain a human body.

Even if they obtain a human body after asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, they will be born in the five turbidities of the Buddha-lands. Their bodies will always be dumb and their mouths unable to speak. Their ears will not hear anything. Such illnesses will afflict their bodies and their minds will be confused;
They will have no food, drink, property, or wealth. They will be far from good spiritual friends and will accomplish all evils. They will also be covered by wrong views;
They will commit many heinous crimes and speak the view of annihilationism, disturbing my Å›rÄvaka disciples who uphold the precepts purely and cultivate merit, and being tainted by evil.

If a person has inferior faculties and inferior diligence, does not seek the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle or Pratyekabuddha Vehicle, but gives rise to the view of annihilation in the MahÄyÄna path, it will be difficult for them to even attain a human body, let alone seek the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle or Pratyekabuddha Vehicle.

It is like a clay pot with many holes, if it is filled with oil or water, it will all leak out and be destroyed.
Why is this?
It is because the vessel is defective.
If there are sentient beings whose faculties are not mature, they are also like that pot.
Good man!

It is like showing various treasures to a blind person. In the same way, if one widely shows the MahÄyÄna to those without wisdom, those with pride and indulgence, and those with the view of annihilation, they will not be able to understand it.

In the same way, if one is not diligently seeking the vehicle of the Å›rÄvakas or pratyekabuddhas, and has heavy greed, anger, and delusion, up to those whose faculties are not ripe for the vehicle of the Å›rÄvakas, if the MahÄyÄna path is explained to them, they will also not be able to understand.
It is like a person who does not carry armor and weapons but enters a battle formation. After entering, he will certainly obtain immeasurable suffering;

In the same way, if those whose faculties are not ripe and are not diligently seeking the vehicle of the Å›rÄvakas or pratyekabuddhas are shown the MahÄyÄna vehicle, it is also like this, and they will certainly obtain immeasurable suffering.
Therefore, good sons!
A wise person first observes sentient beings and then explains the Dharma, with a mind of loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, and a mind of benefiting, not a lazy mind;

With a mind of patience, without arrogance or indulgence, without jealousy or stinginess, with a mind of concentration, he expounds the Dharma for others, and also does not cause others to fall into evil destinies or unfavorable circumstances.
Therefore, the TathÄgata is able to know the minds of others and save sentient beings, expounding the Dharma according to their beliefs, and adorning himself with great adornments.

If he expounds the Dharma for bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, he always uses the causes and conditions of great compassion, in order to sever all the afflictions of sentient beings, and expounds the Dharma to deliver them from the ocean of existence.
In order to cause them to accomplish the One Vehicle among the Three Vehicles, he expounds the Dharma, and never wishes to cause them to fall into birth and death when expounding the Dharma.

He expounds the Dharma by discriminating the aggregates, he expounds the Dharma by discriminating the sense bases, he expounds the Dharma by discriminating the elements, he expounds the Dharma by discriminating the path of the desire realm, he expounds the Dharma by discriminating the paths of the form realm and formless realm.

Not for the sake of existence in this world, not for the sake of existence in the next world, not for the sake of the existence of practice, not for the sake of the existence of mental thoughts, not for the sake of the existence of mental activities, not for the sake of the existence of mental intentions, not for the sake of the existence of ignorance, up to not for the sake of the existence of birth, old age, sickness, and death, not for the sake of the existence of practiced and unpracticed beings, up to practicing and non-practicing cessation, for the sake of teaching the Dharma of the non-arising of all thoughts.
What is called practice?
Practice is called dying here and being born there. If one can cover this birth and death, it is called the cessation of practiced and non-practiced.

The same is true of what I am now saying. If one commits the ten evil deeds and burns up the seeds of humanity, one is not a vessel for the Å›rÄvakas or pratyekabuddhas, and the seeds are destroyed. Such a fool deceives others, saying:

If one says to oneself:
I am of the Great Vehicle.

And can destroy the great army of afflictions and defilements of all beings, and also abide in the eightfold right path for the sake of beings and enter the city of fearlessness, then it is impossible.
Why is it so?

If there are sentient beings whose deportment is pure, who are endowed with a sense of shame and remorse, who fear the afterlife, who are far removed from all unwholesome dharmas, who delight in all wholesome merits, who give rise to a mind of great compassion for sentient beings, who are also able to deliver all from suffering and distress, who protect those who are afraid of birth and death, who are not attached to their own happiness but rejoice in the happiness of others, who are always diligent and mindful without giving up, whose minds delight in tranquil concentration and who abandon flattery, deceit, and deception, who are well aware of karma and the fruits of karma, who are not attached to the five desires, who are not tainted by the eight worldly dharmas, who delight in contemplating the aggregates and elements, who are like someone whose head is on fire or whose clothes are on fire, who abide in the Å›rÄvaka lineage,

Being obstinate and delighting in breaking the precepts, if hearing praise of the Mahayana,

Upholding the ten wholesome deeds, do not destroy my Dharma.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Practicing the foremost enlightenment;
Free from Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, I speak for the sake of purifying beings.

At that time, after the World-Honored One had spoken this verse, in the great assembly, there were countless hundreds of thousands of people, many of whom were confused and deluded, had severed their wholesome roots, spoke of the non-existence of cause and effect, and were heading towards evil paths. The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good men!

At that time, the World-Honored One, for the sake of innumerable hundreds of thousands of beings, in accordance with their minds spoke the Dharma of the Four Truths.
